content.title: Aggregate Demand
content.definition: Aggregate demand (AD) represents the total quantity of goods and services that all economic agents (households, firms, government, foreigners) are willing and able to purchase at each price level during a given time period. It is the sum of consumption (C), investment (I), government spending (G), and net exports (X - M): AD = C + I + G + (X - M). The AD curve slopes downward because higher price levels reduce real wealth (wealth effect), increase interest rates (interest rate effect), and make domestic goods more expensive relative to foreign goods (exchange rate effect).

definitions_glossary.aggregate_demand: Total spending on domestically produced goods and services at each price level: AD = C + I + G + NX
definitions_glossary.consumption: C = Household spending on goods and services - largest component of AD (typically 65-70% of GDP)
definitions_glossary.investment: I = Business spending on capital goods (equipment, structures) + residential construction + inventory changes
definitions_glossary.government_spending: G = Government purchases of goods and services (excludes transfer payments which affect C through income)
definitions_glossary.net_exports: NX = X - M = Exports minus imports - contribution of foreign trade to aggregate demand
definitions_glossary.ad_curve: Downward-sloping curve showing inverse relationship between price level and total quantity demanded
definitions_glossary.wealth_effect: Higher P reduces real value of money holdings → households feel poorer → consume less → AD falls
definitions_glossary.interest_rate_effect: Higher P increases money demand → higher interest rates → lower investment and consumption → AD falls
definitions_glossary.exchange_rate_effect: Higher P makes domestic goods expensive relative to foreign → exports fall, imports rise → NX falls → AD falls
definitions_glossary.ad_shifter: Factor that changes AD at every price level - changes in C₀, I, G, NX, or expectations shift entire AD curve
definitions_glossary.autonomous_spending: Spending that doesn't depend on current income - includes government spending, autonomous investment, autonomous consumption
definitions_glossary.induced_spending: Spending that varies with income - consumption that increases when income rises (MPC × Y)
definitions_glossary.demand_shock: Sudden change in any AD component that shifts the AD curve - positive shock shifts right, negative shock shifts left

key_points: AD = C + I + G + (X - M): Total spending equals consumption + investment + government purchases + net exports
AD curve slopes downward: Higher price level → lower quantity demanded due to wealth, interest rate, and exchange rate effects
Wealth effect: Higher P reduces real value of cash, bonds → people feel poorer → spend less
Interest rate effect: Higher P → higher money demand → higher interest rates → less I and C
Exchange rate effect: Higher P → domestic goods expensive → exports fall, imports rise → NX falls
AD shifters: Changes in consumer confidence, investment opportunities, fiscal policy, monetary policy, foreign income, exchange rates
Consumption is largest component: ~68% of US GDP, determined by disposable income, wealth, expectations, interest rates
Investment most volatile component: Sensitive to interest rates, business confidence, expected future profits, capacity utilization
Fiscal policy shifts AD: Increase G or decrease T → AD shifts right. Decrease G or increase T → AD shifts left
Monetary policy shifts AD: Lower interest rates → more I and C → AD shifts right. Higher rates → AD shifts left

examples.title: 2008-2009 Great Recession - AD Collapse
examples.description: Financial crisis triggered massive negative AD shock. Consumption fell as households lost wealth (housing, stocks) and faced credit constraints. Investment plummeted as firms cancelled projects amid uncertainty and tight credit. Result: AD shifted left sharply. Real GDP fell 4.3% (2008 Q4 to 2009 Q2). Unemployment rose from 5% to 10%. Government response: fiscal stimulus (ARRA) and monetary expansion to shift AD back right.
examples.context: Massive AD contraction from wealth destruction and credit crisis
examples.data: Real GDP: -4.3% (2008Q4-2009Q2). Consumption fell 3.1%, Investment fell 23%. Unemployment: 5% → 10% (BEA, BLS data)

examples.title: 2021 Post-COVID Inflation - AD Surge
examples.description: Massive fiscal stimulus ($5+ trillion), pent-up demand from lockdowns, and Fed's zero rates shifted AD right sharply. Supply couldn't keep up (supply chain disruptions). Result: AD exceeded AS at previous prices → inflation surged. Demand for goods especially strong (people substituted from services during COVID). AD growth of ~10% nominal GDP in 2021 - fastest since 1984.
examples.context: AD expansion faster than AS could accommodate → inflation
examples.data: Nominal GDP growth: 10.7% (2021). Personal consumption expenditures: +11.9%. CPI inflation: 7.0% by Dec 2021 (BEA data)

examples.title: 1930s Great Depression - Keynes's Insight
examples.description: AD collapsed: Consumption fell as income dropped, Investment collapsed from pessimism and bank failures, Net exports fell from global depression. Classical theory predicted wage/price falls would restore equilibrium. Keynes argued: falling wages reduce income → reduce consumption → further AD decline (paradox of thrift). Government spending (G) needed to replace collapsed private demand. This analysis birthed modern AD-focused macroeconomics.
examples.context: The historical crisis that led to development of AD theory
examples.data: US real GDP fell 27% (1929-33). Consumption fell 18%. Investment fell 87%. Unemployment: 25% (NBER historical data)

examples.title: Japan 1990s - Persistent AD Weakness
examples.description: Asset bubble burst in 1991 destroyed household wealth (real estate, stocks). Investment fell as firms became 'zombies' with excess debt. Despite near-zero interest rates, AD remained weak - 'liquidity trap.' Government spending increased but couldn't fully offset private sector retrenchment. Demonstrates: when private AD components collapse, even aggressive fiscal policy may struggle to restore full employment.
examples.context: Long-term AD deficiency despite policy efforts
examples.data: Japan's GDP growth: 1.1%/year (1991-2000) vs 4%+ (1980s). Investment/GDP ratio fell from 32% to 24%. Deflation from 1999

examples.title: China 2000s - Investment-Led AD Growth
examples.description: China's rapid growth driven by high investment (45%+ of GDP) and net exports. Government directed bank lending to infrastructure and manufacturing. AD growth of 10%+ annually for decades. Concerns: excessive reliance on I, low C share (only 35% of GDP vs 68% in US). When global demand fell in 2008, China responded with massive fiscal stimulus (4 trillion yuan) to maintain AD.
examples.context: Alternative AD composition with high investment share
examples.data: China GDP growth: 10%/year (2000-2010). Investment: 45% of GDP. Consumption: 35% of GDP. 2008 stimulus: 4T yuan (13% GDP)

content.statement: Aggregate demand represents total spending in the economy at each price level, composed of consumption, investment, government purchases, and net exports. Understanding AD and its determinants is essential for analyzing business cycles, the effects of fiscal and monetary policy, and the causes of recessions and inflations.

explanation.intuition: Think of aggregate demand as the total dollar amount everyone in the economy wants to spend on stuff. Households buy groceries, cars, and houses (C). Businesses buy machines, build factories, and stock inventory (I). Government buys roads, schools, and military equipment (G). Foreigners buy our exports while we buy their imports (NX). Add it all up: that's AD. When the price level rises, people don't want to spend as much: their cash buys less (wealth effect), borrowing gets expensive (interest rate effect), and foreign goods look cheaper (exchange rate effect). So AD slopes downward. When people get optimistic, taxes fall, or the Fed cuts rates, everyone wants to spend more at every price level - the whole AD curve shifts right.
explanation.key_insight: The revolutionary insight is that AD determines output and employment in the short run - not just prices. In classical economics, prices adjust instantly so AD only affects the price level, not real output. Keynes showed that with sticky prices and wages, AD shortfalls cause recessions with involuntary unemployment. This is why recessions aren't just bad luck - they're demand failures that policy can address. Understanding AD components reveals policy levers: Cut taxes or increase G → AD shifts right. Fed cuts rates → I and C rise → AD shifts right. This is why governments and central banks actively manage AD to stabilize business cycles.
explanation.technical_details: AD function: Y^d = C(Y-T, r, wealth) + I(r, expectations) + G + NX(e, Y, Y*). Consumption: C = C₀ + MPC(Y-T) - br where C₀ is autonomous consumption, MPC is marginal propensity to consume, b is interest sensitivity. Investment: I = I₀ - hr where I₀ is autonomous investment, h is interest sensitivity. Net exports: NX = NX₀ - mY + m*Y* - θe where m is marginal propensity to import, e is exchange rate. AD curve derived from IS-LM: IS gives r(Y), substitute into AD components. Result: Y = f(P) where ∂Y/∂P < 0. AD shifts when: C₀, I₀, G, or NX₀ change; or when tax rates change; or when interest rates change at each P level (monetary policy).

mathematical_formulation.consumption_function: C = C₀ + MPC × (Y - T) where MPC ∈ (0,1)
mathematical_formulation.investment_function: I = I₀ - h × r where h > 0 is interest sensitivity
mathematical_formulation.net_exports_function: NX = NX₀ - m × Y + m* × Y* where m is marginal propensity to import
mathematical_formulation.equilibrium_condition: Y = AD (output equals aggregate demand in equilibrium)
mathematical_formulation.ad_curve_slope: dY/dP < 0 due to wealth, interest rate, and exchange rate effects
mathematical_formulation.is_curve_derivation: Y = C₀ + MPC(Y-T) + I₀ - hr + G → Y = [1/(1-MPC)][C₀ - MPC×T + I₀ - hr + G]

consumption.determinants: Disposable income (Y-T), wealth, interest rates, expectations, credit availability
consumption.volatility: Relatively stable - consumption smoothing across income fluctuations

investment.share_of_gdp: 15-20% in US, but most volatile component
investment.determinants: Interest rates, business expectations/confidence, capacity utilization, tax policy
investment.volatility: High - 'animal spirits' cause large swings, amplifies business cycles

government_spending.determinants: Policy decisions, automatic stabilizers, political economy
government_spending.note: Excludes transfers (Social Security, Medicare) which affect C through income

net_exports.share_of_gdp: Usually negative in US (trade deficit ~3-5% GDP)
net_exports.determinants: Exchange rates, relative income levels, trade policy, competitiveness

verified_claims.derivation: By national income accounting: GDP ≡ C + I + G + NX. In equilibrium Y = GDP = AD ✓

Three effects: (1) Wealth: Higher P → lower real M/P → less C. (2) Interest rate: Higher P → higher money demand → higher r → less I. (3) Exchange rate: Higher P → appreciation → lower NX. All effects negative ✓
Y = C₀ + MPC(Y-T) + I + G. Solve: Y(1-MPC) = C₀ - MPC×T + I + G. Thus dY/dG = 1/(1-MPC) ✓
